header.title: Women Engineers On the Rampant Sexism of Silicon Valley | WIRED
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Five female engineers discuss the sexism of the tech industry and why greater diversity and inclusion makes better products for everyone. Still haven't subscribed to WIRED on YouTube?  http://wrd.cm/15fP7B7. CONNECT WITH WIRED Web: http://wired.com. Twitter: https://twitter.com/WIRED. Facebook: https://facebook.com/WIRED. Pinterest: https://pinterest.com/wired. Google+: https://plus.google.com/+WIRED. Instagram: http://instagram.com/WIRED. Tumblr: http://WIRED.tumblr.com. Want even more? Subscribe to The Scene: http://bit.ly/subthescene. ABOUT WIRED: WIRED is where tomorrow is realized. Through thought-provoking stories and videos, WIRED explores the future of business, innovation, and culture. Women Engineers On the Rampant Sexism of Silicon Valley | WIRED

commentThread.commentText: It's interesting that a lot of comments take offense to the presence of the video at all. I am an employer, and I can relate to the stories that these women are telling. It's a hard problem to solve, because the culture is self-perpetuating. The people who work in these positions are overwhelmingly men, this has an impact on, before anything else, how interested girls are in pursuing these things even into high school when you're starting to build these foundational skills. When you get past high school, where your classes are kind of balanced, you're just a bit different for being the girl who likes tech, you get to go to college where you go into your industry specific classes and find yourself to be one of the only 5 girls in your lab of 40 people, and you wonder why that is, and whether you fit in. But then you power through despite that, and you start applying for jobs, and you get passed up for some and you aren't sure why, but you also don't have experience past your education so you play it off, but you start to have doubts about whether you belong. And then you finally get into the job after all of that, and then you get exposed to the things that these women brought up, and you're used to that because the whole way along you've been having to prove yourself to yourself and everyone else. As an employer, I have had women in IT roles who get second guessed and have people do end-runs around them to their managers or colleagues to get some kind of verification or validation because they're not willing to accept the judgment of these people for reasons that they try to justify based on things not related to these people's gender. These things are generally unfounded and not really grounded in reality, but instead be questions about trust or competence that aren't backed up by any reason to doubt their trustworthiness or competence. Managing under these circumstances is excessively frustrating because now I have to go and defend my staff's judgment or smooth things over, or even just tell the customer to get over it. This is frustration that are not caused by the female staff member, but by the cultural expectation. I'm not willing to take it out on them, I don't give them more leverage than male staff, but at the same time, I am willing to advocate for them just the same, but more frequently. If it's a real concern then I take it to heart, but if it's a matter of trusting that they are competent without some evidence that they've acted anything other than competently, then those concerns aren't coming from a fair place, and I'll tell you that. But I can believe that other managers, maybe in larger companies, aren't able to see things as directly, aren't willing to advocate for their staff the same way, and will hold it against the women themselves when people go over their heads to voice unfounded concerns based on their expectation of what a person in that position should look like. I'd even admit that I might be affected by these things subconsciously, but I've worked with enough good women to try my best to consciously avoid those judgments. But I think one of the trickiest things is that the environment makes it hard for women to take on tech roles, and then it makes it hard for them to keep tech roles, and it also makes it hard for people who want to hire women. The reality might be that given two people with equal skill, the man might be less trouble for an employee than the woman, not because of anything that the man o r woman do differently, but because of how other people perceive them. In order to overcome this problem in the long term we need to be able to at least not favor the man over t he woman because of that. But even that's not enough, we need to find a way to encourage girls who are interested in tech to not be scared away because it's a boy's club, and we need to let them develop their skills without feeling out of place. And THEN we need to hire them, and advocate for them. I don't think we need a 50/50 split of women and men in tech, and it could be that fewer women are interested in tech than men, and that's OK. I don't think we should be pushing women into doing a job they're not interested in to fill a quota. However, I do feel that every girl that's interested in tech and every boy that's interested in tech should have the ability to develop their knowledge and skills in a safe environment, and have an even shot at a career in it. A lot will need to change before that is going to happen. I know we still have growing to do just based on the number of people who object to this video being posted at all.

Yeah, not really sure how much of this is really "rampant sexism" or something else. Maybe, in some cases, you feel like you're getting hurt because you, yourself, go into situations with your own presumptions and fears that make you somewhat hypersensitive to "microaggressions" that that weren't meant in a negative way or even seen in a negative way by others who aren't paying especially close attention to these things? Or maybe, in some cases, it isn't really sexism but rather you standing out in some way, being different in some way to those your peers have come accustomed to? You know, someone new who you don't know are trying to figure out? You probably do it too! Let's say you are in a group of America n Engineers and suddenly there's someone who just migrated from a foreign country that, or at least you assume so, might have different customs and the person might have a different way of speaking, might not understand your humor due to not being immersed in the same culture as you, or there might even be a thick accent or other kinds of language barriers. This might make you act slightly different towards them as you're trying to get to know the person and figure them out. You do that with every new person you meet, but the more distant they are from your own social circles and group of colleagues they are, the more different you act towards them, especially in the beginning. Maybe you don't know if they understand your humor, so you hold back on it a little, making it slightly awkward. Maybe you are trying to be nice and you speak more slowly, more clearly so they can understand you, because you assume a foreigner might have issues understanding normal, every-day speech, which that particular person might and people assuming differently might annoy them or make them feel like you think they are stupid. Things like that. This isn 't racism. This isn't even really you necessarily being a closed-minded asshole. This is pretty normal. This can happen due to age differences, too, or ANYTHING, really, that makes them stand out from those people you have come accustomed to. Just like it can happen to a woman joining a group of men. Or a man joining a group of women. And with women nowadays, especially women who are seen in videos like these, it's made even more unnatural because it is this vicious cycle of presumptions from both sides, some wanting to please and forgo uncomfortable situations (and failing) and some being annoyed by all that and being especially offended or offensive, that just makes this worse than it has to be. And no one side is to blame for this, even though this video seems to assume so. And look at the statement at 2:58! If I wanted to be petty, I could be offended by this too. This seems to me like she is assuming that men are sexist because they lack the sense of imagination to empathize with women and see how they feel, while she's ignoring that she might be doing the same thing, just gender-swapped. If men can't possibly imagine what it's like t o be a woman, in any field, neither can women imagine what it's like to be a man. And believe me, it's not as easy for us as some of you seem to believe. There was also the whole thing about a group of people asking "What's in it for me? Why would I support this?" as if that's in any way exclusive to "men's clubs". It is not. Not at all. Isn't that exactly what you are asking with this video? You, as a minority group, are asking for changes, asking to be treated differently, asking for the systems and norms to change to make you feel more comfortable. So you are asking "what's in it for me and my group?" whenever decisions are being made. This is what people and groups do. They act in their own interest. I doubt most of you would do your engineering work for no credit, no money, no other benefits, even if it helps some other person. Because when you do your work, when you put effort into something (and changing norms, like what's being asked here, does take effort), you want to be compensated in some way. Meaning, you are asking what's in it for you whenever you take on any kind of project. So why wouldn't others? Why is that suddenly a bad thing when that person isn't you? And then there is that whole nonsense about " withou >t woman engineers we wouldn't have a lot of things because women made things dude aw yeah women we are great!". Congratulations? So have a lot of men? More men than women, most likely? With a lot discoveries and inventions of women done using methods, tools and previous discoveries and inventions that were likely made by men? So? Why are you drawing special att ention > to woman engineers doing their jobs well (that they got paid for) when previously in the same video someone's complaining about situations in which men are like "WO W! You're a woman AND an engineer!? AMAZING!" That is kind of what you are doing later in the same video. Engineers are useful to society, regardless of gender. Wow! "I love my job, I love making stuff. I just want the industry to look more like me." That sounds incredibly narcissistic, really. I mean, I get what she's saying and I don't even really have an issue with it, but if I were to turn this around, if a group of male engineers enjoys being among their kind and someone who's very different, say, some women, then join that group and the group of men says they wish the field they worked in was more like them again, t hat is suddenly sexism. Women doing the same is normal and empowering and WHOOO we are great, worship us! Seriously, fuck right off with this. I don't care about statistics, about how many people of a certain group are in a certain field. Because there are just as many statistics that counter any argument made with that statistic. If there's a place that GENUINELY discri minates based on gender, race, whatever. Then that is a problem. And I mean really discriminates and not call you "sweety" once while asking you to pass the salt at a company dinner. If a school or a culture REALLY discourages or even forbids people of certain groups to follow a certain career path that they want to do and could be great at, that is a problem and needs fixing. If someone, doing the same work, at the same quality and quantity, in the same place, gets paid l ess on the base of gender, race, etc., that is also bullshit that people should fight against. That is worth our time and energy. But all this pseudo shit, this microaggression nonsense and this "muh statistics" and "oh no I am in a minority! Quick! Restrict people's freed oms, di >scriminate by gender/race to fit quotas! Tell people what to do!!" needs to stop. Anyway. Good video. Almost perfect. 5/7!

And while your anecdote is valid and should be taken into consideration, it's really just that- an anecdote, much like the accounts of these women; it's limited and biased and to expect anymore than this is unreasonable. moreover, while the tech industry is getting "better" from your point of view, things are not so a- okay as a whole. We'll still privy to all sorts of inequity, whether its based on sex or on class or on merit, what have you. These women's predicaments, whether reified or not (that interpretation can be different depending on the individual who may or may not sympathise with them), are symptoms of grander social ills, not the sole arbiters of them. In addition I never framed these in terms of "accomplishments" persay (accomplishment implies some kind of end goal and obviously progress does not pertain to a simple and dichotomous task- completion relationship, it's more of a continuum; in essence this label is too limited) but rather as small and necessary steps that attempt to unravel millennia of social programming, but certainly not sufficient in doing so holistically. also about your high school. it seems more like it's the institution who is culpable of inculcating and reinforcing these prejudices, as is usually the case. of course people reinforce this as well but I assure you these high school girls didn't have some inherent inclination to make hair brushes rather than pens prior to being taught this. they are rather young, after all. Additionally, you frame it in a way that makes it seem as though making hair brushes was such a bad thing. both are utensils that are useful in their own ways and preferences between the two are pretty arbitrary.

When it comes to my high school engineering courses, it was not a comment on how women perceive engineering and design(I have a good friend who wants to go into Mechanical Engineering and is nothing like that), they were told by the teacher that they were to make hair brushes, while we, a predominantly boys class with two girls in it, made pens. I was not saying that we say that "Oh this is fine, ultimate equality has been achieved," but that things are getting better, and we need to see that. But the increasing thing that I am seeing, at Univeristy and in the circles that I m in which involve women, is that things are just as bad as ever. As I stated in another comment(which I presume you have not seen, just as a matter of that it's real far down) the tech industry, while it may not seem like it, is very old. The prejudices that come from it being that old exist, like the fact that women are not taken seriously, are dissuaded from going into these fields are all correct, but they are becoming less and less so. But the idea that we should let up is absurd, in fact, we should be louder than ever, because change is happening, and people are loud, but not with the right message. The message should be "Oh wow! Things are getting better! Let's keep doing this and make things EVEN better!" But that is not what people are saying. They keep saying that things are just as bad as they always were. This could not be further from the truth. I could not find a single scholarship for Software Engineering, that was not only for girls. It was literally impossible. Is this progress?

Tenacious Tacos there tends to be this antagonism towards women stating their point of view because it is automatically viewed as misandrist and discriminatory against men when paradigms like sexism and racism are not symmetrical because of the historical precedents where one group has been favored more than another. These scholarship initiatives are merely attempts to balance an unbalanced game. Not to take from opportunities that were already there- supplement not supplant. There's enough to go around, mind you. Now your individual perception of what these phenomenons mean as it relates to you and your individual life, which themselves are based on your limited perspective as the skin encapsulated ego that you are, is different. the fact that these prejudices are happening to some lesser extent is not the issue, the issue is that it still exists and it is substantiated both by anecdote, history, and sheer statistics. Frankly, if you're a guy, as it seems to be the case, you will not understand the importance of keeping a wary eye of specious compromise because you have and will not experience these things in the way women do and thats a fact. It's not to give you guilt of being you or persecuting that, it's more a matter of helping you be aware of these things- the fact that we all have be to be more cognizant of the world around us and be accountable for the terrible consequences of our preconceptions. Just because you do not experience this, it does not mean it does not happen to a greater degree than the one you maintain. also, my comment about your high school was also not about the perceptions of the girls themselves more as an explanation of why those girls percieve the way they do. again the institution, i.e the faculty, are most responsible for this.

Linda Godinez What are we disagreeing about? I say that while the concerns that these women present, while valid, are not as bad as they say, however, these are problems that would not have gotten better if not for the efforts by the women which went into these fields in the first place. These are problems, and like all problems, should not be ignored, and when change, positive or negative effects these problems, we should speak up more. I am not some all knowing being, some thing of ultimate good, but that does not mean that my points are invalid, as this video has changed my very own opinions, as have the things stated by my female friends. You are correct that I am a guy, but I ask you, if I am aware that these things are an issue and am actively trying to correct them, does that make my own opinions any less valid, does that make yours more valid? While I am not all knowing, I do know the answer to that, it is no. Everyone should be given an equal chance, no matter their race, gender, or some other bullshit that people judge others unjustly on. And I do understand the importance, my friends, both of whom are brilliant women, way smarter than me in any capacity should be taken seriously because I know that they will have amazing ideas. The idea that a brilliant plan or idea is dismissed because of the fact the fact that the person presenting it is a women makes me almost physically sick.

Tenacious Tacos 
what we disagree about is the degree to which they occur and their gravity. you say that they are aggrandized unnecessarily while I say that they are diminished to a rather miniscule amount by most, not necessarily you. we cannot reconcile this with mere YouTube comments, these are determined from our limited perspective with experiences in tow. on that note, it is not to say that your view is any less but that it is limited in scope because of the objective limitations of both your mind and body. your reality is different than the one women experience on a daily basis thus you can only make suppositions of what there lives are like based on your own experiences. Also, not to say that you cannot attempt to understand these intricacies as you might, but that it will not be as complete enough to determine with a great certainty that the trials and tribulations (to more or less a degree) are just not as bad as they say they are.

I know this thread is rather old (3 months since the latest post), but I just felt the need to clarify something that I think the conversation was touching on while maybe not fully articulating. I think one of the dangers that may come as a consequence of what Tenacious Tacos was pointing out is a backlash due to a feeling that the efforts that are already being put forward are meaningless. Just coming from a psychology background and knowing how human behavior is molded so well by reward and punishment, I could see progress being halted if the progress that's already been made isn't acknowledged properly. It kills the morale of everyone involved. It's just something I worry about.
